title: 108_hr1722
content: The "Rural Rental Housing Act of 2003" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Key findings are outlined in the Act. Congress finds a growing need for rural rental housing, with many households lacking access to affordable units and living in inadequate or overcrowded conditions. In rural America, overcrowding is a significant issue with 28% of rural households facing serious housing problems. Approximately 1 million rural renters have multiple housing issues, and 2.6 million rural households live in substandard conditions. One-third of rural renters pay more than 30% of their income for housing, while 20% pay over 50%. 92% of rural renters with significant housing problems pay more than 50% of their income for housing. Rural economies face limited job opportunities due to factors like remoteness and low population density, hindering access to technology and investment. Local expertise is often focused on farming or natural resource industries. Rural areas also have less access to credit compared to metropolitan areas. Federal Government investment in rural rental housing has significantly decreased over the past decade. Federal spending for rural rental housing has been cut by 73% since 1994, and rural rental housing unit production financed by the Federal Government has been reduced by 88% since 1990. This decline in investment exacerbates the challenges faced by rural economies, such as limited job opportunities and access to credit compared to metropolitan areas. To address the scarcity of rural rental housing, the Federal Government must collaborate with various entities including State and local governments, private financial institutions, philanthropic organizations, and nonprofit groups. The Federal Government must collaborate with various entities to address the scarcity of rural rental housing. SEC. 3 defines key terms. The Act defines key terms related to rural rental housing, including "eligible project," "eligible rural area," and "eligible sponsor." Eligible projects involve acquiring, rehabilitating, or constructing rental housing for low-income families in rural areas with a population of not more than 25,000 outside urbanized areas. Eligible sponsors can be public agencies, Indian tribes, for-profit corporations, or private nonprofit corporations with a focus on housing or community development in rural areas. The term "qualified intermediary" refers to an entity with a track record in providing technical and financial assistance for housing and community development activities in rural areas. The term "qualified intermediary" refers to an entity with a track record in providing technical and financial assistance for housing and community development activities in rural areas. The term "Secretary" means the Secretary of Agriculture. The term "State" means each of the several States of the United States, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, the Trust Territories of the Pacific, and any other possession of the United States. SEC. 4. RURAL RENTAL HOUSING ASSISTANCE. The Secretary can provide assistance to eligible sponsors for projects through loans, grants, and other forms of financing. Eligible sponsors must submit an application including a certification that the housing will remain affordable for low-income families for at least 30 years. The Secretary prioritizes providing assistance to eligible projects for very low-income families and in low-income or underserved communities. This assistance can be in the form of loans, grants, or other financing options, with a requirement that the housing remains affordable for at least 30 years. The Secretary allocates assistance among states based on rural substandard housing and poverty levels, ensuring each state receives a minimum of $2,000,000. Assistance under this Act cannot exceed 50% of the total project cost, with exceptions allowed. Assistance under this Act cannot exceed 75% of the total cost for projects involving up to 20 rental housing units for very low-income families. SEC. 5. DELEGATION OF AUTHORITY. The Secretary may delegate authority for distribution of assistance to qualified intermediaries in the State for up to 3 years, renewable at the Secretary's discretion. Applications for delegation of authority can be solicited from qualified intermediaries, who must certify matching funds from sources other than this Act. The Secretary may delegate authority for distribution of assistance to qualified intermediaries in the State for up to 3 years, renewable at the Secretary's discretion. Applications for delegation of authority can be solicited from intermediaries, who must certify matching funds from sources other than this Act. The application should include a description of the State or area to be served, poverty and housing conditions, applicant qualifications, assistance sought, and a proposed distribution plan. The Secretary may delegate authority for distribution of assistance to qualified intermediaries in the State for up to 3 years, renewable at the Secretary's discretion. Multistate applications may be sought by the Secretary from qualified intermediaries. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $250,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008.
